title: 104_hr3992
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Speaker appoints five members, ensuring a mix of political affiliations and non-Congress members. Appointments must be made within three months of the Act's enactment, with members serving for the Commission's duration. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairman and a majority required for a quorum. The Commission shall hold its first meeting at the call of the Chairman, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The Chairman is selected from among the members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and health benefits under the Medicare Program. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will introduce legislation based on the Commission's recommendations within 3 months of receiving the report. Legislation for Medicare trust funds' solvency must be introduced in Congress within 3 months of receiving the Commission's report. If not voted on within 3 months, the legislation will be considered highly privileged for consideration. Legislation introduced in the House or Senate must be voted on within 3 months, otherwise, it will be considered highly privileged for consideration. If not approved within this timeframe, the legislation will be discharged from committee and a motion to proceed will be treated as privileged. Legislation introduced in the House or Senate must be voted on within 3 months. If not approved within this timeframe, a joint resolution endorsing the recommendations in the report will be considered privileged for consideration. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Act addresses personnel matters related to the Commission. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing Commission duties. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative support. The Chairman can determine the compensation of the executive director and staff without adhering to certain pay regulations. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairman can also procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission will come from available funds for the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
